fields.Title of Presentation: <p>Investigating psychological well-being among international college students in the United States</p>
fields.Description/Abstract: <strong>Background:<span> </span></strong><span>The influx of international students to the United States has been steadily increasing, with a substantial number of students choosing to pursue their education in this diverse and culturally rich nation</span><strong>. Purpose:</strong><span> The current study delves into the psychological well-being of international students in the US, aiming to uncover the extent of well-being and its relationship with demographics and background characteristics. </span><strong>Methods:</strong><span> A secondary data analysis of </span><em>N</em><span> = 13,242 international students from the 2022 American College Health Association’s National College Health Assessment (ACHA-NCHA) provided insight into their well-being, stress levels, gender, grade level, and ethnicity. </span><strong>Results:</strong><span> Most students reported moderate to high psychological well-being, underscoring their resilience. However, gender, grade level, and stress levels emerged as significant predictors of well-being, with female and graduate students facing particular challenges. Interestingly, while effective in univariate analyses, ethnicity did not play a pivotal role in predicting well-being in the final model, suggesting mediation by factors like acculturation stress and social support. </span><strong>Conclusion:</strong><span> The findings hold implications for educational institutions, policymakers, support service providers, and researchers, emphasizing the importance of tailored support and policies to enhance the well-being of international students.</span>

attachments.filename: Psychological Well-Being of International College Students_Poster.pptx
